job_title: Supervisor in Central Valley, CA
pros: Pros to this agency would be the populations we got to work with. It's a very humbling and rewarding job. The staff embedded in the programs care very deeply about their clients.
cons: The executive team is made up of friends and intertwined marriages who behave like the cool kids at school. They will exclude anyone who is not in that clique. The only way to move up the ladder is to know or be liked by someone in that clique. The CEO is possibly the least professional individual of them all. He has zero leadership qualities, is rude and arrogant. This is the culture that is created at the very top. It definitely trickles down and poisons the well.

job_title: Administrative in San Diego, CA
pros: The programs are helping people and many staff are dedicated and caring.

review_title: Great pay for management, not client centered as it once way
job_title: Program Manager in San Diego, CA

cons: It seems that the company as a whole has shifted from client centered to productivity centered.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: There is a good work/life balance.  They are very understanding about time off for family, and have a genuine concern for mental health or substance abuse issues. The company as a whole does some awesome work in the communities where they work.
cons: The running joke is you only get promoted if you are incompetent.  The company has done a great job cleaning house after serious mishandling allegations, but there are a few old timers still hanging on that really need to go.  There is still the atmosphere of fear, and no empowerment of capable employees whatsoever.  There is also still a gaping lack of useful communication.  It seems like the COO, and other long time corporate management are scared to share too much with other departments, for fear of losing their control, causing major issues with inter departmental cooperation.

review_title: KINGS COUNTY ACT - AWFUL, AVOID LIKE THE PLAGUE, CLUELESS MANAGEMENT
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Hanford, CA
pros: The pay is pretty decent for a new clinician, I was satisfied. The "line staff" as we were called once (case managers, clinicians, employment/peer support) are ALL wonderful people with GOOD hearts.
cons: Absoutely clueless management, the VP at Kings County ACT is based out of San Bernardino and NEVER is avilable. It is sad to see this ship sink under his leadership. VPs and other upper management are not supportive at all often replying to e-mail with "I don't have time for this figure it out" and  leading to program managers leaving or having their hands tied with no direction, leaving the rest of the staff with NO DIRECTION. Unethical practices have been witnessed going on due to the severe LACK OF QUALIFIED STAFF. "ClinicalSup" could not even sign off on hours, and never bothered to set up supervision time until all the clinician who were there left. Not too sure how this agency is proving services now. I know in the Central Valley finding sites to get your hours may be hard, but SAVE YOUR SANITY AND AVOID KINGS COUNTY ACT LIKE THE PLAGUE (THEY PROBABLY WILL LOOSE THEIR CONTRACT). Senior Management needs a shake up REAL FAST! They are the reason why money is tight, INVESTIGATE THEM!

review_title: Great people and company very poor pay
job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: MHS is very good about promoting from within.  There are also may opportunities for training and community involvement.
cons: The pay flat out sucks.  MHS is a non-profit so supposedly can not afford to pay their staff the going market rate. A lot of senior people were promoted from within the company and were promoted too quickly and do not possess the managerial skills needed to be good, productive and consistent managers.  Everyone seems to be very scared of breaking the chain of command even when it is not clear what the chain is.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: love the work-life balance program hours are 7:30-4pm and program is closed when everyone goes home! Lots of holidays including birthday holiday and floating holiday, access to all company forms and information on a portal, very high tech company with IT assistance, opportunity for growth, all programs are different, everyone cares about the clients, and opportunity to apply at other programs if you want to grow within or try something new, experience with electronic health record, great stepping stone as you are working county programs, lots of trainings available, comfortable office setting. Love working for MHS!
cons: pay is lower in certain positions than others in the field such as clinical positions, no company parties which means you don't meet too many people outside of your program if you aren't sharing a building, or have any reason to go to the home office.

job_title: Facilitator in Rancho Cucamonga, CA
pros: - was able to have income as a trainee
cons:
- poor HR management 
- terrible QA 
- terrible IT service 
- poor supervision 
- unrealistic documentation due to terrible structure and support 
- terrible structure, really no structure 
- not great incentives 
- toxic workplace
- drama 
- support for toxic people who only threaten to sue, but no help or voices heard for the hard working positive people 
- feeling unsafe 
- again, terrible structure for help, support and documentation and supervision

review_title: Chaotic atmosphere fed by continual crisis management.
job_title: Program Staff in San Diego, CA
pros: Working for this type of non-profit provides an opportunity to help others, work as part of a team and contribute to your community.
cons: Highest staff turnover (including management) that I have ever experienced.  Employees appear to leave MHS because: management is unresponsive to employee concerns; staff personal safety concerns; staffing issues wherein many months pass by before vacant positions are filled; compensation which for some positions is below par; slow and cumbersome employee expense reimbursement; management priorities that change with the wind; unresolved staff/management accountability issues; self-promoting, arrogant attitude of some management staff; staff negativity and rampant low morale stemming from above issues and overall, a few "bad apples" spoiling things for the majority of employees.  Although I cannot speak for all the MHS programs, this one had a particularly toxic culture.

job_title: Administrative in San Diego, CA
pros: Some folks in senior management seemed to actually care about doing the right thing.  Surely they came into the company truly wanting to help needy people.
cons: A bunch of con artists that just want to suck $ out of the government, while lining their own pockets. Awful culture of gossip and immaturity, including those in senior management that should really know better.  Long-term employees are overpaid, so they of course cover the backs of those that sign their checks.  Kim Bond is the worst con artist of them all. Don't buy into the "kind" image she's trying to portray.

job_title: Mental Health Program Manager in Fresno, CA
pros: Opportunity to learn, grow clinically, serve in program that helps vulnerable children/families. Liked flexibility in schedule, good supervisors, VP, training. MHS has a great reputation despite near implosion from former executives. The organization has lots of great potential for people in the field of behavioral health.
cons: Organizational trauma in last year has made people skeptical and unsure of future, medical benefits are lacking. Turnover in program made it difficult to stabilize.

review_title: Mental Health Systems has been nothing short of an amazing company to work for.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colton, CA
pros: They make you feel like a valued and respected part of the team. The sense of community and respect that they show is second to none.
cons: There isn't a lot of mid level positions, there are entry level and then the leap to Program Manager, then to VP are huge ones. Being in the field they are in there isn't a lot of money to be made if you aren't in a management position.

review_title: Mental Health Systems cares about it's employees
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Escondido, CA
pros:
There is always room to grow and explore the diversity of the company, within the numerous programs run by MHS.  MHS recognizes quality leadership skills and also provides valuable opportunities for trainees and interns to meet the extensive requirements to obtain licensure as a Mental Health Clinician. 
If you are in the field because you truly want to improve lives, MHS is the place to be!
cons: There should be annual wage reviews

job_title: Journey Substance Abuse Counselor in Bakersfield, CA
pros: Drug and Alcohol  counseling program for women, parenting workshops, career success
cons: Mangers without vision, managers that do not inspire or motivate. Lack of Integrity and character. unethical behavior, lack of training with themselves. Leaders that all about them and does not trust staff.

job_title: Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Feeling fulfilled about serving a population that really needs it . Good place to get your 1 year experience and then move on.
cons: Lowest pay in the area. More concerned about quantity then quality. Unrealistic demands on employees sometimes at the expense of patient and employee safety. Upper management gets paid very well but none of it trickles down to the people who actually see the patients (dont believe me just read the recent news article in the union tribune about the company). Not a company I am proud to work for. Turn over is huge. People get there one year experience and then move on.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fresno, CA
pros: none at all everything they do is a lie.
cons: all upper management is ripping off the company pressuring people to spend less and less also 0 room for moving on up.   president of the company a non profit let me say that again a non profit company gave herself a 200,000 $ raise and was making over 300,000 a year at one point. the whole company is in debt and I am worried that us actually working for the cause are going to be the ones that are left with disaster.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: You feel like you're making a difference...until reality sets in that the quality of the services provided to help people come secondary to management's desire to take home a paycheck. I thought I'd be helping people, but I thought wrong.

review_title: Do yourself a favor stay away from MHS
